blog.name: mamadragon-daenerys
blog.description: Kaylee| 18| AL, USA| Pan/Demi| Intersectional Feminist| totally into Democratic Socialism| pro-sex work & pro-choice (duh, not a feminist if you aren't pro-choice & sex work)| Targaryen loyalist| a Knight of Daenerys Stormborn’s Queensguard| Jonerys shipper| Daenerys & Emilia Clarke stan| dragon obsessed| I don't ship abusive/toxic/unhealthy relationships| aspiring actress| Ravenclaw| Sun in Capricorn, Moon in Pisces, Rising in Taurus| Eclectic Witch| Tumblr nickname: shoplifting lady knight

tags: im not entirely sure how to tag this
summary: I just read an article about Kit Harington having to go to therapy after Jon’s death and resurrection and he apparently was...
body:
I just read an article about Kit Harington having to go to therapy after Jon’s death and resurrection and he apparently was wondering if he could even act! And I was just last night thinking about how much I love his acting while I was watching his scene with Littlefinger in the crypts. I mean, just watching his face before he chokes Littlefinger is awesome bc he’s so good at his job! Even had a barely noticeable angry lip twitch. And I’m just like “THIS IS ACTING RIGHT HERE!”. He barely changed is facial expression at all and you could just tell how angry he was getting bc of all the little movements that weren’t that noticeable if you weren’t paying close attention.

I’ve watched a couple of his movies so I know he’s as good an actor as Emilia or Sophie or any of them really so I was just like “KIT WHAT ARE YOU TALKING ABOUT?!” as I read that. I just love him y’all!

summary: "I think it's always been about two things for me," Harington said. "About dysfunctional families — or families in general,...
caption: “I think it’s always been about two things for me,” Harington said. “About dysfunctional families — or families in general, always where the best drama is — and the everlasting idea that people who seek power are very often the last people who should have it.

tags: เกมล่าบัลลังก์
summary: I think it’s always been about two things for me. About dysfunctional families – or families in general, always where the best...
text: I think it’s always been about two things for me. About dysfunctional families – or families in general, always where the best drama is – and the everlasting idea that people who seek power are very often the last people who should have it. Unfortunately, we’re leaving ‘Thrones’ with a Joffrey as the President of the United States of America.
source: Kit Harington in Variety.

reblog.comment: Kit Harington in Variety.

summary: Arya was playing the ‘game of faces’ in Season 7 - whereby you have to lie convincingly and if you can’t, you lose.  Jon is...
body:
Arya was playing the ‘game of faces’ in Season 7 - whereby you have to lie convincingly and if you can’t, you lose. 

Jon is playing the ‘game of faces’ in Season 7 too, lying convincingly and winning.

Avatar and header by @ragekitn

summary: I have always loved your blog and your responses, for they are always insightful.  Two questions: 1- after watching the official...
question: I have always loved your blog and your responses, for they are always insightful.  Two questions: 1- after watching the official trailer, do you still believe in the Dark!Dany theory? If going by the scene of Jon and D*ny in the crypts, presumably post parentage reveal, she doesn't seem threatened. 2--What do you make of Sophie's revelation of Sansa not finding romance in s8, and desiring "self love?" Could her arc be similar to Elizabeth Tudor, the famed "Virgin Queen" who never married?
answer:
Hey, nonnie!

Thank you for your kind words. That’s always nice to hear! :)

1- after watching the official trailer, do you still believe in the Dark!Dany theory? If going by the scene of Jon and D*ny in the crypts, presumably post parentage reveal, she doesn’t seem threatened.

I’ve actually written a meta on the official trailer that you can find here if you’re interested in knowing my thoughts on it in depth but to answer your question, yes, I’m still fully on board with the Dark!Dany theory because, at this point, I don’t think this is a theory. I think Dark!Dany is already here and has been here for at least 2 seasons now. Its just a matter of the writers making it transparent in narrative. 

Also, you state in your ask that the scene of Jon and D*ny in the crypts is presumably post parentage. There’s really no way of knowing that at this time because there’s no context for that scene. 

It could just as easily be a scene of Jon going to the crypts after arriving in Winterfell and feeling conflicted about having bent the knee, a moment D*ny interrupts. 

It could be a scene post Jon meeting the Northern Lords and being rejected by them because of him losing his crown and D*ny comes there to comfort him. 

If this post parentage reveal, it doesn’t immediately follow that D*ny knows about it. Maybe Jon is hiding from her and she finally finds him in the crypts. 

That I’m getting at is that there are a multitude of reasons why that scene exists and it doesn’t all come down to D*ny finds out who Jon is and comforts him.

And even if that were the case, it doesn’t also mean that Dark D*ny suddenly isn’t a thing anymore. Is she still the woman who burned the Tarlys? Is she still the Stallion that Mounts the World? Did she feed men to her dragons? The answer is still yes, independent of the reason why she’s in those crypts.  

2–What do you make of Sophie’s revelation of Sansa not finding romance in s8, and desiring “self love?” Could her arc be similar to Elizabeth Tudor, the famed “Virgin Queen” who never married? 

I’ve said this in the past and I’ll say it again but I don’t put much stock in what actors on this show say. However if we are going to discuss what Sophie said, let’s look at the exact quote, shall we? 

Sansa doesn’t want to fall in love with anyone; I think she’s trying to fall in love with herself, and that’s the only love that counts.

Sophie doesn’t say Sansa won’t find romance in season 8. What she said is that Sansa doesn’t want to fall in love which is another way of saying that Sansa is emotionally isolated, which is no great surprise since she’s been that way since season 6, something that was highlighted even further during season 7. That’s not to say that she won’t fall in love or even that she’s already in love, whether or not she wants to be. 

As for the Elizabeth I parallel … Honestly, nonnie and sorry for saying this, but I’m so sick and tired of this being brought up in relation to Sansa over and over again because there’s no basis for it. Sansa’s narrative arc has always been linked to her marriage prospects and fertility, from the very first episode of this series. If she shares parallels to any real life queen those would be Elizabeth of York (queen to Henry Tudor) and Eleanor of Aquitaine (queen to Henry II). Eleanor of Aquitaine is actually, I’m pretty sure, the inspiration behind Queen Alysanne who again shares many parallels with Sansa. All three of these queens (2 real, 1 fictional) were extremely influential, had power in their own right and incidentally were also wives and mothers. 

Thanks for the ask!

tags: the man was ruling just for a week or sth
then he literally put it on Sansa’s shoulders
summary:
They: Jon, you are the new King in the North!
Jon: Thanks guys...
... one week later...
Jon: Oh Gods, I made a huge mistake;...
body:
They: Jon, you are the new King in the North!

Jon: Thanks guys…

… one week later…

Jon: Oh Gods, I made a huge mistake; it’s too much responsibility…

Jon: Here, Sansa, you have the North! I am gonna chill on an island for a while.

Sansa: Get marry they said… it will be fun they said…

reblog.comment:
They: Jon, you are the new King in the North!

Jon: Thanks guys…

… one week later…

Jon: Oh Gods, I made a huge mistake; it’s too much responsibility…

Jon: Here, Sansa, you have the North! I am gonna chill on an island for a while.

Sansa: Get marry they said… it will be fun they said…

trail.content_raw:
They: Jon, you are the new King in the North!

Jon: Thanks guys…

… one week later…

Jon: Oh Gods, I made a huge mistake; it’s too much responsibility…

Jon: Here, Sansa, you have the North! I am gonna chill on an island for a while.

Sansa: Get marry they said… it will be fun they said…
trail.content:
They: Jon, you are the new King in the North!

Jon: Thanks guys…

… one week later…

Jon: Oh Gods, I made a huge mistake; it’s too much responsibility…

Jon: Here, Sansa, you have the North! I am gonna chill on an island for a while.

Sansa: Get marry they said… it will be fun they said…

summary: Kit Harington: “Auf der Straße schrien mich die Leute an: Bist du tot?”
title: Kit Harington: “Auf der Straße schrien mich die Leute an: Bist du tot?”
body:
Kit Harington resümiert seine Vergangenheit bei “Game of Thrones”: Eine bestimmte Phase innerhalb der Serie bezeichnete der Schauspieler als “dunkelste Zeit” – zum Glück konnte eine Therapie helfen.

Über Jahre hinweg einen Charakter zu spielen, der einem nicht gerade ähnelt – besonders, wenn man selbst als junger Erwachsener noch dabei ist, sich selbst zu finden – ist nicht einfach. Noch weniger, wenn man dabei von Millionen Menschen vor dem Fernseher beobachtet und mit der TV-Figur gleichgesetzt wird. Und so war Kit Haringtons Zeit als Jon Snow auch nicht immer nur eitel Sonnenschein – und der letzte Drehtag in gewisser Weise auch eine Erleichterung: „Ich zog das Kostüm aus und es fühlte sich an, als ob ich mich häuten würde“, sagte Kit Harington im Interview mit „Variety". „Ich war sehr emotional.“

“Ich mochte den Fokus, der auf Jon lag, wirklich nicht”

Als schwierigste Phase beschrieb Harington die Zeit, in der die Serienfigur Jon Snow immer wichtiger für die Show wurde: „Meine dunkelste Zeit war, als die Show sich immer mehr um Jon drehte, als er starb und zurückkam“, so Harington im Gespräch mit dem Magazin. „Ich mochte den Fokus, der auf Jon lag, wirklich nicht.“

Auch die Fan-Reaktionen intensivierten sich nach dem Tod der Serienfigur in der 5. Staffel – und Harington, dessen dunkle Locken längst zu einem unverkennbaren Erkennungsmerkmal geworden waren, konnte sich kaum verstecken: „Auf der Straße schrien die Leute mich an: ‘Bist du tot? ’ Alle Neurosen eines Schauspielers - und ich bin so neurotisch wie jeder andere - werden verstärkt, wenn man so sehr im Fokus steht.“

“Es war eine wackelige Zeit für mich”

So viel Aufmerksamkeit erzeugt Druck – ein Druck, den Harington auch in seinem Privatleben verspürte: „Es war keine sehr gute Zeit in meinem Leben”, sagte er zu „Variety". „Ich hatte das Gefühl, ich müsste mich als der glücklichste Mensch der Welt fühlen, in einer Zeit, in der ich mich sehr verletzlich fühlte. Es war eine wackelige Zeit, die viele Menschen wohl in ihren 20er-Jahren haben. Zu dieser Zeit begann ich mit der Therapie und fing an, mit Leuten zu sprechen. […] Ich war sehr dankbar für das, was ich hatte, aber ich war auch unglaublich besorgt darüber, ob ich überhaupt schauspielern konnte.“

Sein Leben mit Jon Snow, mit allen Höhen und Tiefen – Kit Harington wird es vielleicht nicht vermissen, aber doch auch sicher nicht missen wollen: Beim Table Read zur letzten Staffel, dem gemeinsamen Durchlesen der Szenen vor Beginn der Dreharbeiten, kamen dem Schauspieler die Tränen, wie er „Variety” bestätigte: „Das Ende von Jons Reise, was auch immer es sein mag … ich war zufrieden damit, wie seine Geschichte endete.“

Wie seine Geschichte weitergeht, erfahren wir ab dem 15. April. Dann läuft die finale Staffel 8 auf Sky.

(Bilder: Getty Images / ddp)

summary: Kit Harington had therapy to cope with 'Game of Thrones' fame
title: Kit Harington had therapy to cope with 'Game of Thrones' fame
body:
Kit Harington has revealed he started therapy as he adjusted to the worldwide fame brought by starring in Game Of Thrones.

The British actor has played Jon Snow in HBO’s fantasy behemoth since 2011 and will pull on his famous fur cape for the final time when season eight airs in April.

Harington was largely unknown when he first appeared in Game Of Thrones but is now one of the most recognisable faces on TV thanks to the show.

Speaking to Variety, the 32-year-old admitted to feeling the strain when Jon’s prominence in the show steadily increased and his own fame rocketed.

Read more: 10 questions Game of Thrones must answer in S8

He said: “It wasn’t a very good time in my life. I felt I had to feel that I was the most fortunate person in the world, when actually, I felt very vulnerable.

“I had a shaky time in my life around there – like I think a lot of people do in their 20s. That was a time when I started therapy, and started talking to people. I had felt very unsafe, and I wasn’t talking to anyone.

“I had to feel very grateful for what I have, but I felt incredibly concerned about whether I could even f***ing act.”

The eighth and final season of Game Of Thrones arrives in April and Harington said US TV Network HBO have not rested on their laurels with the series’ previous success and have instead went “balls out”.

He added: “They could have easily set the same budget as they did for season seven, but they went bigger.”

And while the series’ end is being kept tightly under wraps by HBO, Harington, who met his wife Rose Leslie on Game Of Thrones, did offer fans a clue as to the fate of Jon.

Read more: Game of Thrones S8 episode lengths

“The end of Jon’s journey, whatever that may be… I was satisfied with how his story ended”, he said.

Game of Thrones returns to Sky Atlantic for its final season on 15 April. You can watch the first seven seasons on NOW TV.


Reporting by PA
